title: 106_hr3995
content: The "District of Columbia Receivership Accountability Act of 2000" requires District of Columbia receivers to adhere to specific rules outlined in the Act. A District of Columbia receiver is defined as an official appointed by the United States District Court or the Superior Court of the District of Columbia to oversee government departments. Each District of Columbia receiver must promote financial stability and management efficiency in the administration of government departments. They are also required to control costs and ensure they align with regional and national standards to promote efficient and cost-effective administration. Each District of Columbia receiver must administer government departments using accepted accounting principles and fiscal practices. They consult with the Mayor and Chief Financial Officer when preparing annual budgets. The receiver must submit estimates of expenditures and appropriations to the Mayor for inclusion in the annual budget of the District of Columbia. The Mayor forwards the estimates to the Council for action, without revision but with recommendations. The Council can comment or make recommendations but cannot revise the estimates. Exceptions apply to this subsection. Exceptions to the subsection include departments, agencies, or offices of the District of Columbia government under a receiver allowing the Mayor and Council to revise the budget, and the District of Columbia Housing Authority receiver appointed in 1995. This subsection applies from fiscal year 2001 onwards. An annual audit by an independent auditor is required for departments under a District of Columbia receiver. An annual audit by an independent auditor is required for departments under a District of Columbia receiver, with exceptions for certain departments and the District of Columbia Housing Authority receiver appointed in 1995. The audit is to be conducted jointly by the receiver and the Mayor or their designees, with necessary information and assistance provided to the auditor. In 1995, a District of Columbia receiver appointed for procurement purposes must ensure full and open competition through competitive procedures, with exceptions for nominal amounts or urgent public needs. The District of Columbia Housing Authority receiver appointed in 1995 is exempt from certain procurement requirements related to the delivery of articles or services, certification of single source supply, and technical or professional services performed by the contractor. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF APPLICABILITY OF ANTI-DEFICIENCY ACT. Nothing in subchapter III of chapter 13 of title 31, United States Code, may be construed to waive the application of the provisions of such subchapter which apply to officers or employees of the District of Columbia government to any District of Columbia receiver. Speaker of the House of Representatives. Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate.
